Name: Chamorro
comm_Syst: "manot […] considered as expressing 'a set.' When more than one ten is expressed, fulu is used" (p.100)

Name: Palauan
comm_Syst: Krämer (1919:331) assumes power numerals over 1000 to be influenced by Western languages

Name: Yapese
comm_Source: Müller (1917:125f.): similar, but one power less

Name: Nguluwan
comm_Source: Eilers' list of numerals ends at 600

Name: Nukuoro
comm_Source: Carroll & Soulik (1973): same numerals (except for 10) up to 10^8
comm_Syst: C&S (1973: 465): madaangahulu for objects, hulu in enumeration & compounds only; H&J (1984:72): hulu/mada for 10

Name: Nauru
comm_Syst: beyond 10^6, counting returns to 1 (iwuit) & continues recursively (Kayser 1993:68)

Name: Kosraean
comm_Syst: Vesper (1970) gives siŋaul for 10 (but no higher power numerals)

Name: Gilbertese
comm_Syst: Bingham (1922:15) gives tebwina for 10 objects and teñaun for 10 people (or 100 coconuts [p.17])

Name: Marshallese
comm_Syst: for power numerals in specific counting systems, see Erdland (1906:204f.); analysis in Bender & Beller (subm.)

Name: Pingelapese
comm_Source: Eilers (1934:461-463) reports similar, yet more complicated numerals (except for 10) up to 10^9

Name: Mokilese
comm_Source: Eilers (1934:397) reports similar, yet more complicated numerals (except for 10), and up to 1000 only

Name: Mortlockese
comm_Syst: Girschner (1913:171) reports eṅoal for rapid counting and most objects, säk for living beings

Name: Namonuito
comm_Source: Quackenbush (1968:201-203) reports a pattern in line with Trukic (with 1000 = ngaraj)

Name: Carolinian
comm_Syst: Fritz (1911:19) reports sél for 10,000 and äpingit for 100,000; both J&M (1991) and Fritz (1911) report eyáf for units of 10 coconuts

Name: Woleaian
comm_Source: unclear whether Krämer (1937)'s power numerals for 100,000 onwards apply also to Lamotrek, or only to Fais

Name: Tobian
comm_Source: Eilers also renders numerals reported by Pickering, Hale, and  Hellwig
